senators.name: Richard Shelby
senators.bio: Richard Craig Shelby (born May 6, 1934) was first elected in 1986. He is the Chairman of the United States Senate Committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs. Originally from Birmingham, Alabama, Shelby studied law at the Birmingham School of Law. He has served as city prosecutor and worked as a U.S. Magistrate for the Northern District of Alabama.
senators.platform: Make education decisions at the local level. Require a balanced budget. Make insurance more portable, expand health savings accounts, reduce frivolous lawsuits, and emphasize preventive care.

senators.name: Lisa Murkowski
senators.bio: Lisa Ann Murkowski (born May 22, 1957) has served in the Senate since 2002. She became the state's senior senator when Ted Stevens retired in 2009. Murkowski served in the House and was eventually elected majority leader.
senators.platform: Fixing one-size-fits-all education mandates from Washington, D.C. Smart spending reductions are needed to target the nation’s growing, unsustainable debt while avoiding future sequestration scenario. Ensuring that all Alaskans have access to affordable, quality health care

senators.name: John McCain
senators.bio: Sidney McCain III (born August 29, 1936) was the Republican presidential nominee in the 2008 United States presidential election. McCain was in the United States Navy and became a naval aviator, flying ground-attack aircraft from aircraft carriers. He retired from the Navy as a captain in 1981 and moved to Arizona, where he entered politics.
senators.platform: Insists upon responsible federal budgeting in order to fully enable Americans to pursue financial success. Education is the key to building a strong and competitive workforce in a global economy. Meet the American public’s continuing need for quality health care at an affordable cost.

senators.name: John Boozman
senators.bio: John Nichols Boozman (born December 10, 1950) attended the University of Arkansas, where he played football for the Arkansas Razorbacks, and graduated from the Southern College of Optometry. He won a special election in 2002 to the United States House of Representatives, where he served as assistant majority whip and sat on the Republican Policy Committee. Boozman was elected to the United States Senate in 2010.
senators.platform: Institute a Balanced Budget Amendment, that will stop the government from spending beyond its means. Introducing portability to the market to ensure you don’t have to change your insurance just because you change your job. We must look to forward-thinking solutions to our problem with illegal immigration, not the failed policies of the past.

senators.name: Barbara Boxer
senators.bio: Barbara Levy Boxer (born November 11, 1940) was elected senator in 1993. Boxer previously served in the U.S. House of Representatives. Boxer graduated from Brooklyn College. She worked as a stockbroker for several years before moving to California with her husband. Boxer won the 1992 election for the U.S. Senate. She previously held the record for the most popular votes in any U.S. Senate election in history, having received 6.96 million votes in her 2004 re-election.
senators.platform: Not running for re-election.

senators.name: Michael Bennet
senators.bio: Michael Farrand Bennet (born November 28, 1964) worked as a Senate page on Capitol Hill in high school. He went on to receive his law degree from Yale Law School, where he was the Editor-in-Chief of the Yale Law Journal. Bennet was elected in the 2010 Senate election where he defeated Republican Ken Buck
senators.platform: Innovations should come from the classrooms and communities that are closer to our kids rather than from the lawmakers in Washington. Start making the tough decisions necessary to put our nation's fiscal house in order. Ensure that the law is enacted effectively and responsibly regarding the Affordable Care Act.

senators.name: Richard Blumenthal
senators.bio: Richard Blumenthal (born February 13, 1946) served as Attorney General of Connecticut from 1991 to 2011. Blumenthal is a graduate of Harvard College, where he was editorial chairman of The Harvard Crimson. He later attended Yale Law School, where he was editor-in-chief of the Yale Law Journal.
senators.platform: Alleviate student loan debt from graduates. Increasing access to safe and affordable prescription drugs. Support efforts to end wasteful and unnecessary tax subsidies for oil and gas companies and agree we should redirect that money to support the development of clean, renewable sources of energy.

senators.name: Marco Rubio
senators.bio: Marco Antonio Rubio (born May 28, 1971) previously served as Speaker of the Florida House of Representatives. He is currently a candidate for the Republican nomination for President of the United States, in the 2016 presidential election. Rubio ran for United States Senate in 2010, and won that election.
senators.platform: Not running for re-election

senators.name: Johnny Isakson
senators.bio: John Hardy Isakson (born December 28, 1944) served in the Georgia Air National Guard (1966–1972) and graduated from the University of Georgia. After 6th District Congressman and Speaker of the House Newt Gingrich resigned, Isakson ran in the February 1999 special election to succeed him, winning by a 40-point margin. He is serving his second term after re-election to the Senate in 2010. He became the senior Senator when Saxby Chambliss retired in 2015.
senators.platform: We must make a budget and cut spending. Support federal assistance programs that help make higher education affordable. The key to health care reform is stimulating competition in a market-based system.

senators.name: Brian Schatz
senators.bio: Brian Emanuel Schatz (born October 20, 1972) served in the Hawaii House of Representatives from 1998 to 2006. He also worked as chief executive officer of Helping Hands Hawaii, an Oahu nonprofit social service agency, until he resigned to run for Lieutenant Governor of Hawaii in the 2010 Hawaii gubernatorial election as the running mate of Neil Abercrombie. Upon his swearing-in, Schatz was the youngest U.S. Senator in the 112th Congress. In the current congress, he is fourth.
senators.platform: Expand early childhood education, giving nationally-recognized programs the resources to reach more low-income and underserved children. Expanding access to health care for every family, and to making the Affordable Care Act work successfully. Support vital funding for federal small business programs.

senators.name: Mike Crapo
senators.bio: Michael Dean Crapo (born May 20, 1951) is a graduate of Brigham Young University and Harvard Law School. Prompted by his brother's death, Crapo successfully ran for the Idaho Senate in 1984. He ran for the open seat in the U.S. Senate in 1998, vacated when Dirk Kempthorne successfully ran for governor. Crapo was elected with 70% of the vote, and became the first Mormon to represent Idaho in the Senate.
senators.platform: Support the Gang of Six efforts and co-sponsored the Cut, Cap and Balance bill in the Senate. Preserve decision-making authority for states, local communities and especially local school boards. Promoting quality care for all citizens must remain a priority of the 114th Congress.

senators.name: Mark Kirk
senators.bio: Mark Steven Kirk (born September 15, 1959) Kirk is a social moderate and fiscal conservative. Born in Champaign, Illinois, he graduated from Cornell University, the London School of Economics, and Georgetown University Law Center. January 2012, Kirk suffered a stroke,[6] and a full year passed before he returned to his congressional duties.
senators.platform: Important to do the work needed to reduce spending and balance the books so that we restore the vitality of a free people. Continue the great American tradition of standing up for human rights. Support the Balanced Budget Amendment to the Constitution, which will legally ensure that the Government keeps its spending under control.

senators.name: Daniel Coats
senators.bio: Daniel Ray Coats (born May 16, 1943) He was in the United States Senate from 1989 to 1999, retired, and then returned in 2011. Coats graduated from Wheaton College in Illinois and Indiana University Robert H. McKinney School of Law. He served in the U.S. Army from 1966 to 1968. After retiring from the Senate, Coats served as U.S. Ambassador to Germany from 2001 to 2005, and then worked as a lobbyist in Washington, D.C. He was re-elected to the Senate by a large margin in 2010.
senators.platform: Not running for re-election.

senators.name: Chuck Grassley
senators.bio: Charles Ernest Grassley (born September 17, 1933) is the current chairman of the Judiciary Committee of the 114th congress. He was chairman of the Senate Finance Committee from January to June 2001 and from January 2003 to December 2006. Grassley previously served in the United States House of Representatives (1975–1981) and the Iowa state legislature (1959–1974).
senators.platform: Favors spending reductions to manage the deficit. Tax incentives to make higher education accessible and affordable for all students who want to pursue an advanced degree. A health policy that helps individuals afford coverage; promotes wellness, preventive care and disease management; takes into account the financial impact on employers, small businesses and taxpayers.

senators.name: Jerry Moran
senators.bio: Gerald W. Moran (born May 29, 1954) served as Chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee for the 113th U.S. Congress, during which he led successful Republican efforts in United States Senate elections, 2014, producing the first Republican Senate majority since 2006. Moran graduated from the University of Kansas and the University of Kansas School of Law. He worked in private law and served as the state special assistant attorney general (1982–85). He was elected to the U.S. Senate in 2010.
senators.platform: Increase the number of qualified teachers in classrooms and maintain flexibility for state. Advance public health innovations, including development of new medicines, medical devices and food safety technology. Opposing reckless spending and working to address our country's economic problems in a fiscally responsible way.

senators.name: Rand Paul
senators.bio: Randal Howard Paul (born January 7, 1963) is the son of former U.S. Representative Ron Paul of Texas. Paul attended Baylor University and is a graduate of the Duke University School of Medicine. Paul entered politics by running for a seat in the United States Senate. Paul has described himself as a Constitutional conservative and a supporter of the Tea Party movement.
senators.platform: Not running for re-election

senators.name: David Vitter
senators.bio: David Bruce Vitter (born May 3, 1961) served in the United States House of Representatives, representing the suburban Louisiana's 1st congressional district. He won a second Senate term in 2010. Vitter announced that he would not seek reelection to his Senate seat in 2016 and would retire from the Senate at the completion of his term.
senators.platform: Not running for re-election.

senators.name: Barbara Mikulski
senators.bio: Barbara Ann Mikulski (born July 20, 1936) has served in the Senate since 1987. Mikulski, who served in the United States House of Representatives from 1977 to 1987, is the longest-serving woman in the history of the United States Congress. Mikulski attended Mount Saint Agnes College and the University of Maryland School of Social Work. She is now the ranking minority member.
senators.platform: Not running for re-election.

senators.name: Roy Blunt
senators.bio: Roy Dean Blunt (born January 10, 1950) was the House Minority Whip during the 110th Congress but after the 2008 general elections announced that he would step down from the position.  In 2011, Blunt was elected vice-chairman of the Senate Republican Conference. He and his son are the only Republicans to have served as Missouri Secretary of State since 1945.

senators.name: Harry Reid
senators.bio: Harry Mason Reid (born December 2, 1939) has served in the senate from 1987. Reid is one of only three Senators to serve at least eight years as Majority Leader. Reid formally announced on March 27, 2015 that he will retire at the end of his current term on January 3, 2017, saying that his recent injuries and subsequent recovery had nothing to do with his decision.
senators.platform: Not running for re-election.

senators.name: Kelly Ayotte
senators.bio: Kelly Ann Ayotte (born June 27, 1968) s the second youngest of the 20 female Senators, and the twelfth-youngest overall. Ayotte is a graduate of Pennsylvania State University and Villanova University School of Law. In September 2010, Ayotte won a close victory over lawyer Ovide M. Lamontagne in the Republican primary for the U.S. Senate.
senators.platform: Simpler, fairer tax code that lowers taxes for families and small businesses. Improving mental health training in schools, supporting local mental health solutions. Prepare our kids for good paying jobs by improving STEM education and manufacturing skills training.

senators.name: Charles Schumer
senators.bio: Charles Ellis Schumer (born November 23, 1950) was elected in 1998, he defeated three-term Republican incumbent Al D'Amato by a margin of 55%–44%. Before his election to the U.S. Senate, Schumer served in the U.S. House of Representatives from 1981 to 1999. He is a graduate of Harvard College and Harvard Law School, he was a three-term member of the New York State Assembly, serving from 1975 to 1980.
senators.platform: Supporting women’s reproductive health care decisions.  Amendment to the Constitution of the United States relating to contributions and expenditures intended to affect elections.

senators.name: Richard Burr
senators.bio: Richard Mauze Burr (born November 30, 1955) worked for seventeen years in private business with Carswell Distributing. He earned a B.A. in Communications from Wake Forest University in 1978. In July 2004, Burr won the Republican primary to seek the U.S. Senate seat being vacated by Democrat John Edwards, who had launched a presidential campaign.
senators.platform: Ensure that every North Carolinian has an opportunity to afford college through sensible reforms to federal student aid programs. Follow the example of North Carolinians and begin to make tough choices and prioritize spending decisions. True health care reform that preserves Americans’ control over their own health care decisions.

senators.name: John Hoeven
senators.bio: John Henry Hoeven III (born March 13, 1957) previously served as the 31st Governor of North Dakota from December 2000 to December 2010. Hoeven was elected to the U.S. Senate in the November 2, 2010 general election. He attended Dartmouth College, where he belonged to the Alpha Chi Alpha Fraternity and graduated with honors. He then earned an MBA from the Kellogg School of Management at Northwestern University.
senators.platform: Additional revenues should come from tax reform and economic growth, not raising taxes. Empower schools, administrators and teachers to create local strategies that prepare students to succeed in a global, high-tech economy. Create competition among insurance companies by allowing them to offer plans across state lines.

senators.name: Rob Portman
senators.bio: Robert Jones Portman (born December 19, 1955) graduated from Dartmouth College and the University of Michigan Law School. He worked briefly in the White House during the first Bush Administration before entering the U.S. House of Representatives. He has been listed as a possible Republican vice presidential candidate in the past two presidential elections.
senators.platform: The Jobs for America plan focuses on budget, tax, regulatory, workforce, trade, energy, and health care proposals. Repeal the health care law that passed in 2010, start over, and replace it with proposals that actually reduce costs and increase competition. Reduce deficits through pro-growth policies and keeping federal spending under control.

senators.name: James Lankford
senators.bio: James Paul Lankford (born March 4, 1968) was the student ministries and evangelism specialist for the Baptist General Convention of Oklahoma.  He stepped down on September 1, 2009, to run for Congress.
senators.platform: Opposition to the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2015. Reauthorize the Elementary and Secondary Education Act and reform No Child Left Behind. A five-year surface transportation reauthorization bill.

senators.name: Ron Wyden
senators.bio: Ronald Lee Wyden (born May 3, 1949) served in the United States House of Representatives from 1981 to 1996. He attended the University of California, Santa Barbara on a basketball scholarship,[4] and later transferred to Stanford University, where he received his Bachelor of Arts in 1971. He received a Juris Doctor degree from the University of Oregon School of Law in 1974. Ensure workers can get a job that will support their families, build their savings and send their children to college.
senators.platform: Student Right to Know Before You Go Act to provide all potential college students with reliable information on what students can expect to make in the workplace. A health care lifeline that benefits us all.

senators.name: Patrick Toomey
senators.bio: Patrick Joseph Toomey (born November 17, 1961) served as a United States Representative for three terms, from 1999 to 2005, but he did not seek a fourth term in compliance with a pledge he had made while running for office in 1998.
senators.platform: Robert Patrick Casey, Sr. (January 9, 1932 – May 30, 2000) he served as the 42nd Governor of Pennsylvania from 1987 to 1995. He previously served as a state senator 1963–68.

senators.name: Tim Scott
senators.bio: Timothy Eugene Scott (born September 19, 1965) was appointed as senator in 2013 after South Carolina Governor Nikki Haley named him to fill the U.S. Senate seat vacated by Jim DeMint. Scott is one of two African Americans serving in the United States Senate, the first African American senator from the state of South Carolina, the first black Republican elected to the United States Senate since the defeat of Edward Brooke in 1979, and the first elected from the South since 1881.
senators.platform: Believe that each of us must fight to protect the unborn.

senators.name: John Thune
senators.bio: John Randolph Thune (born January 7, 1961) previously served as a United States Representative for South Dakota's at-large congressional district. Thune received the degree of Master of Business Administration from the University of South Dakota in 1984. Thune worked as a legislative aide for U.S. Senator James Abdnor from 1985 to 1987.
senators.platform: Support education proposals that give schools the necessary resources and flexibility while keeping them accountable to taxpayers, parents, and students. Enact meaningful reforms to strengthen existing programs, and ultimately put our fiscal house back in order. Change our health care focus to wellness and prevention.

senators.name: Mike Lee
senators.bio: Michael Shumway Lee (born June 4, 1971) has served in the U.S. Senate since January 3, 2011. Lee is a graduate of Brigham Young University (BYU). Lee began his career as a clerk for the U.S. District Court for the District of Utah before serving as a clerk for future Supreme Court Justice Samuel Alito.
senators.platform: Decisions regarding the education of our children are best made at the local level. Start developing a new conservative reform agenda that restores equal opportunity. Tax reform should remove the disincentives for businesses and individuals to be more productive and lead to greater economic growth.

senators.name: Patrick Leahy
senators.bio: Patrick Joseph Leahy (born March 31, 1940) has been in office since 1975. Leahy served as the President pro tempore of the United States Senate from December 17, 2012 to January 6, 2015. He is the most senior senator and took office at a younger age than any other current senator.
senators.platform: No student should be denied the opportunities of a college education because of a family’s financial resources. All who require care should have access, regardless of their income or where they live. Grow Vermont’s economy, secure federal contracts for local employers, stimulate economic recovery efforts, develop a dynamic workforce and enhance Vermont’s historic downtowns and transportation systems.

senators.name: Patty Murray
senators.bio: Patricia Lynn Murray (born October 11, 1950) was first elected to the Senate in 1992, becoming Washington's first female senator. Murray has served as the Senate Majority Conference Secretary since 2007, making her the fourth-highest-ranking Democrat and the highest-ranking woman in the Senate.
senators.platform: Ensuring the American workforce has the skills and training necessary to remain a world economic leader. Expanding access and affordability to post-secondary education for all students. Ensuring access to mental health coverage and services.

senators.name: Ron Johnson
senators.bio: Ronald Harold Johnson (born April 8, 1955) was chief executive officer of PACUR, LLC, a polyester and plastics manufacturer before being elected Senator. He attended the University of Minnesota while working full-time and graduated in 1977 with a degree in business and accounting.
senators.platform: Find a way to give people more flexibility and freedom in their health care choices. Pass a real pro-growth agenda that will promote long term, self-sustaining jobs in the private sector. Move toward more local control and an educational system.
